block.p: Another Yalie at, or Near, the Top

Not for nothing did Yale hire a spokesman with experience in the White House. LAWRENCE J. HAAS, who worked in the Office of Management and Budget and was Vice President Al Gore's communications director, had an all-politics-is-local spin on Mr. Gore's selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as running mate. As a result of that pick, a Yalie will be on the winning national ticket, Mr. Haas declared in an e-mail message (either Mr. Lieberman, '64, Law '67; or George W. Bush, '68). And, he pointed out, there has been an alumnus in one of the top two spots since 1980 (George Bush, '48, 1981-93; Bill Clinton, Law '73, since 1993).

At Last, the School Year's Over

As other students think about heading back to classes, those at the John A. Reisenbach Charter School in Harlem were just celebrating end of the year graduation day yesterday. Reisenbach, one of the first two start-up charter schools in New York City, has a longer day than the typical public school (8:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. instead of to 3 p.m.) and a longer year (205 days instead of 180).

Fathom.com, the for-profit Internet site developed by Columbia University and five other institutions, will announce today that it is adding four high-profile partners: the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, the American Film Institute, the University of Chicago and RAND. The Web site (www.fathom.com) will offer courses, books, trips and other educational material, some of it for a fee and some at no charge. ANN KIRSCHNER, Fathom's chief executive, said that the site was not ready to announce a starting date yet.

The corner of 143rd Street and Convent Avenue in Manhattan near City College will be named after W. HAYWOOD BURNS, former dean of the City University of New York School of Law at Queens College. Mr. Burns, who was killed in a car crash in South Africa four years ago, spent 10 years at City College, where he served as vice provost and dean for urban and legal programs. The street-naming ceremony will be at 10 a.m. tomorrow.

Being able to predict the weather is one thing; coping with its impact is something else. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is giving $42 million over five years to Columbia University's International Research Institute for Climate Prediction so it can help other nations -- especially poor ones -- prepare for drought, floods, hurricanes and other dire weather. ''Climate prediction is not enough,'' said Dr. ANTONIO DIVINO MOURA, director of the institute, which is based in Palisades, N.Y.
JODI WILGOREN, KATE ZERNIKE and KAREN W. ARENSON
